title: Support mapbox-gl 0.22.0
body:
`mapbox-gl` 0.22.0 [is out](https://github.com/mapbox/mapbox-gl-js/releases/tag/v0.22.0), and I'm unable to use it until `mapbox-gl-draw` supports it.

Has draw been testing with 0.22.0? Can this supported version be added?

title: Update API docs regarding style ids and sources
body:
This PR enhances the `API.md` docs to head off confusion for users who are learning to style `mapbox-gl-draw` features, as in this issue: https://github.com/mapbox/mapbox-gl-draw/issues/472

The must-have changes are the clarification of `source` and `id` here: https://github.com/mapbox/mapbox-gl-draw/compare/master...timiyay:feature/api-docs?expand=1#diff-88333ba11114e014e87198d04680144dR395

There's a few optional changes too:

* a second styling example - it's long example for styling for lines and polygons, which compliments the existing point-only example
* extra info on mode transitions, explaining how completed features always transition to `simple_select` (see https://github.com/mapbox/mapbox-gl-draw/issues/472#issuecomment-238578275)

I wasn't 100% on the vocabulary to use when explaining "completed" features. I was attempting to describe a feature that was in the process of being drawn by the user, who then double-clicked to "complete" the feature, and triggered the mode transition.

I also mimicked the use of **BOLD CAPITALISED** statements used in style source. These are arguably overkill, and I'd be happy to change them.

title: Split up interaction_events.test.js into smaller independent units`
body:
Right now any modifications to `interaction_events.test.js` can be a huge pain, because most of the tests in there rely on continuous shared state — so if you modify something towards the top, you'll need to modify stuff below. This was a mistake I made.

Those tests should be split up into smaller, independent units that can be modified without requiring modification of other unrelated tests.

title: Unable to style finished features
body:
I'm using `mapbox-gl-draw` for a basic use case: 

1. users can draw a line to for measure between 2 points on the map
2. user clicks a `start` button to activate drawing mode
3. user draws their line(s)
4. during drawing, the lines are styled black
5. user double-clicks to finish their drawing
6. the feature switches styles, to green lines
7. the user can no longer edit the line

We are currently on v0.4.0 of this library, and are attempting to upgrade to the latest, but we're having trouble figuring out the new flow.

I'm able to get steps 1-5 working, but steps 6 and 7 are eluding me.

I'm unable to figure which mode I should be switching to, to achieve step 7. I'm trying to switch to `static` but, depending on my approach, it fails in a few ways:

1. if I'm listening for `draw.create` or `draw.modechange` events, and then call `changeMode('static')`, it causes an infinite loop. The event listener calls `changeMode('static')` which triggers the event listener which...

2. the line feature disappears (no styling).

What is the process for implementing this basic use case?

title: API functions are not emitting events
body:
Hi guys, I'm not sure if it's an actual issue for you, but just wanted to ask you: what is the point of not emitting events when using API methods? (changes are in this commit: https://github.com/mapbox/mapbox-gl-draw/commit/2de14b4b8638d04c05826af8f51495ca00726ae8#diff-e1d62d8c4965edf0e532dfa19da0891f)

For example now it's not possible to catch the moment when all features are deleted from draw if I use `deleteAll` method. I think it's a bit confusing, because I expect event is triggered no matter how the feature was actually deleted: by user or calling any of the API method. I just want to know that it was deleted and handle this situation in my code. I think using `{silent: true}` option should be optional and it should be options for the actual API methods, so when I call `draw.deleteAll` for example, I can specify `{silent: true}`. But it shouldn't be by default. What do you think?

title: Audit one-handler-per-event system
body:
I'm a little concerned that there might be some reason to take another look at the move in https://github.com/mapbox/mapbox-gl-draw/pull/453/commits/1d4527b5bf33330771d2a4be167722c52c00359c to enforce only one handler per event.

Maybe there's nothing wrong, but here are my concerns:

1. I'm not sure we're currently using the events in a way that expects this everywhere. For example, I wonder if https://github.com/mapbox/mapbox-gl-draw/blob/master/src/modes/direct_select.js#L78 is now subtly wrong, because if its handler fires it means the other `mousedown` handlers won't, right? — but they should.
2. Generally I just kind of find this more confusing than the other way, because we are accustomed to `addEventListener` and EventEmitters where you can attach as many handlers as you want, independently. Why rely on order of operations to filter *all* handlers when you could rely on explicit conditionals to filter those handlers you want to filter?

So because of the first point, I opened this issue because at some point the code should be reviewed to ensure there isn't weirdness around expecting more handlers to be called than will be. (The second point is just my question.)

title: East-west pan can take you to otherworldly longitudes you can't create features at
body:
If you pan the map east-west, you can pass the +/-180 bounds of longitude *indefinitely*. The trouble is that once you're past +/-270, you can't actually create a feature without causing an error.

It seems weird to me that mapbox-gl-js would allow you to pan to longitude 4000 but then not understand when we try to create a point there ... So I'm not sure what the right way to fix this is — to patch things up on our end, or to look upstream.

title: Option to be able to drag the feature in direct_select mode
body:
Hi!

We use this library a lot for our project: https://compstak.com

And recently we released a new version with Google maps replaced by Mapbox GL maps. Everything works like a charm, thanks for your work. But there is one issue and we have a couple users that already complained about it - so it's pretty important for us.

Little story: we use maps for search. And users are able to use different map search tools. One of these tools is so called "polygon search": user just puts a polygon shape to the map and should be able to resize/drag it to perform search. Like this: 

![like this]
(https://i.gyazo.com/51c9cb64ce0671d41ecd5ecf2075b6fe.png)

But the problem is that your library has separate modes for dragging features (simple_select) and for resizing (direct_select). So it's not possible for us to allow users to drag and to resize polygon at the same time. (And it used to work when we had goole maps - so that's why users complain about it).

Here is my attempt to solve this issue by creating new mode. I called if `mixed` mode (but you can suggest better name). Basically it's just a mix of `simple_select` and `direct_select` modes. 

The work is still in progress, and I have to write some tests at least. But just let me know what do you think about idea of this mode. And what else I should implement here.

Thanks!

title: Support null Geometry
body: Currently we do not support null geometry because there is no way to represent this on the map. That said, it is valid GeoJSON. We could keep it in the store and just not render it. It would probably mean we'd need to protect each mode from being started with it...

title: Support GeometryCollection
body:
We should be able to do this without too much work.

It should work much like multi_feature except that the features should be built by looping over geometries rather than coordinates.

title: Add `getSelected()` function that returns GeoJSON
body:
As we're trying to fine tune the API for v1, I was wondering about this.

Why not return GeoJSON of the selected features? Then `get` and `getSelected` would return equivalent data.

title: Standardize code style
body:
I think it's probably a worthwhile exercise to refactor the library so that it all follows, as much as reasonable, a more consistent code style (e.g. using `var`/`let`/`const`, using default params, using arrow functions, etc.). Seems like a few fairly dissimilar code styles have accumulated over time.

Though this is of course not a vital fix, I think it will make the library a little easier to read and build on over time.

title: Drop `vertex` for `position`
body: Currently Draw refers vertex's both internally and in the styling guide to describe what GeoJSON calls a [Position](http://geojson.org/geojson-spec.html#positions). This is a bit confusing, we should always use the GeoJSON term unless there isn't one.

title: Touch support
body:
Draw _mostly_ works via touch right now. There are three outstanding issues:

- No way to delete nodes
- No way to move features or nodes or create new nodes.
- Difficult to complete shapes.

Solutions:

- Add touch + hold, then drag to drag things.
- Make the delete button delete nodes, not shapes, if a node is selected.
- touch + hold to complete shapes

title: Remove settimeouts from map event toggles after upstream fix
Switch from hot to cold less frequently
body:
Right now the biggest perf issue in GL draw relates to switching features from the hot layer to the cold layer. I wonder if we can hold multiple features in the hot layer, and do less frequent hot-cold exchanges.

We could set a limit of xx features or vertexes in the hot layer, and gradually start dropping the oldest features once that limit is hit.

title: Use multiple cold sources when rendering large numbers of features
body: To make Draw render quickly we use a hot and a cold source where the hot source is all the features that need to be updated on the screen and cold is all the features that don't need to be updated. As a feature becomes stable we move it from hot to cold forcing us to rerender the cold source. As the number of features and size of those features grows this rerender becomes slow. I think breaking the features into a set of cold sources will help with this. My thought is the the id of the feature can be used as part of a hash function to bucket into the same source quickly.
